story:
--- please read "updates" section for more current information ---


About Surya's heart conditions

Surya is a two and a half year old boy who lives in South India. He was born with several heart conditions which he desperatly needs a surgery(s) for:

Double outlet right ventricle (DORV)
That  means the pulmonary valve, which should bring oxygen-rich blood to the body, is situated in the wrong heart chamber which contains low oxygen blood. So the body can not be provided with oxygen-rich blood. 

Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) and Absent pulmonary valve

There is a hole between Surya's lower heart chambers (VSD) and the pulmonary valve is poorly developed.


Why Surya needs your help

Surya's parents are already in debt from going to hospitals and getting extensive testing done for their son's condition. They both come from poor families and additionally Surya's father just got kicked out of the little shop he worked in because the building owner sold the place.

They would do anything to help their son but it's not easy getting that much money if you are born poor in India. About 4000 Euro should cover the cost for surgery, hospital stay and medicine required.

Since he was born Surya spent most of the time at home with his mother. Normally children in India play in the streets starting from a young age but Surya's parents are worried that other children might be too rough for him and his fragile heart. They also have to do their best to prevent Surya from getting sick, even just a cold would be much harder on him than on healthy kids.

Surya needs this surgery in order to live a longer and better life but without financial help his parents will not be able to afford it.

Other ways to help out

Of course spreading the word about Surya and this fundraising campaign for his surgery will be greatly appreciated.

If there are any medical professionals out there reading this I would be happy to send the hospital reports and X rays of Surya's heart and would be grateful about professional opinions.

Also if anyone can help by donating some perks it could help a lot.
Thanks!

story:
We are Cancer United

Hello! We are Cancer United and we need YOUR help to make our C U FITTER project a reality. By contributing to our project you will be helping us build a unique, pioneering special rehabilitation gym space for people at any stage in their battle against cancer. 

Current research indicates that exercising and maintaining a healthy body is vital in the prevention of cancer. Additionally, physical exercise helps the recovery process and the prevention of a recurrence. We believe that people who have the enormous stress of battling this life changing disease deserve to have an environment where they can exercise and improve their fitness, without having to worry about being judged for how they look, what they're wearing and how they perform. 

All your contributions will help us to build the C U FITTER gym in West Sussex. The gym will provide a specialised rehabilitation space where patients can come and receive personal training, exercise classes and support from qualified professionals who they can form close relationships with.

CU Fitter also offers patients the chance to become part of the Cancer United support group where they can share experiences, receive peer to peer support and enjoy the social activities the group offers. 

This CU Fitter project is a pilot scheme for all people battling cancer in West Sussex, we aim to expand the CU Fitter project across all of the UK so that cancer patients receive the proper fitness training and support that they deserve. 

SHARE: www.igg.me/at/cufitter

What We Need & What You Get

We hope to raise £40,000 so that we can do the following:

  • Convert the disused building we have been gifted into the two storey C U FITTER special rehabilitation gym (£28,500)
  • Pay for the plumbing and electrics (£5,000)
  • Pay for the flooring, walls and interior decoration (£4,000)
  • Pay for all the gym equipment (£2500)

For supporting us and being such fantastic people you will receive these amazing rewards:

  • £1 - Personal thank you email!
  • £5 - Above + Updates about our project via email!
  • £10 - All of the above + Personal thank you letter in the post!
  • £25 - All of the above + Certificate of contribution!
  • £50 - All of the above + Cancer United sports shirt!
  • £100 - All of the above + Your name on our website as a top contributor!
  • £200 - All of the above + Personal thank you video from the team!
  • £500 - All of the above + Your name on a plaque in the gym!
  • £1000 - All of the above + 1 year advertising on our site OR 3 PT sessions!
  • £2000 - All of the above + 2 year advertising on our site OR 6 PT sessions!
  • £5000 - All of the above + 5 year advertising on our site OR 15 PT sessions!
  • £10,000 - All of the above + 10 years advertising on our site + 20 PT sessions + Come and have a 5* dinner and drinks with the team!

SHARE: www.igg.me/at/cufitter

If we don't reach our entire goal then your money will still be massively appreciated and will be put towards:

  • Funding the exercise classes for our members
  • Buying equipment for these classes
  • Helping raise awareness for the Cancer United support group
  • Providing transport for our members who cannot travel alone

If you can't donate, you can still be our mate!

We understand that some people simply can't afford to donate, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Make some noise about our campaign, it will be a massive help and we'll appreciate it greatly! Tell your friends, family, pets, everyone you know!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools, as well as sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter and any platform you use!

We are all united by cancer, we are all Cancer United.

SHARE: www.igg.me/at/cufitter

story:
WHAT WE DO

Imagine being 32 years old, having 34 surgeries in 9 months, having both legs amputated above the knees, missing fingers, and severe damage to your hands and forearms.

Imagine if these injuries were your daily struggle- all day, every day, for the rest of your life. What would you miss? What would you do to have the chance to do what you used to take for granted? What would you do to feel the wind again, catch a fish or even participate in some water sports- the chance to do what ordinary people do.  Sergeant First Class Aaron Causey (please view the video included) is one of 1600 multiple amputee veterans the BLUE WATER WARRIORS Foundation is trying to help through innovative rehabilitation programs away from the daily grind of military hospitals

 WHAT WE NEED

We are trying to raise ($10,000+) in order to purchase medical and safety equipment to fit out our custom built vessels. The vessels are custom built for the purpose of making the water accessible to those in wheelchairs or on prosthetic limbs and their families. The programs we offer are for all injured veterans to assist in their rehabilitation.  We take injured veterans and their families out on the water to feel the wind again, catch a fish, or spot a whale.  Your donation, however small, can go towards providing revolutionary means to achieve rehabilitation and reclaim lost capabilities.  Your assistance helps us to help those who have given so much in defense of our country and our way of life. 

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

When a 28 year old triple amputee veteran asked us if we could take him, his wife and daughter fishing how could we say no.  How could we say no to someone who has given everything but his life for us and his country?  How can we not assist those whose lives are forever changed for doing what they believe in?  We believe we have to help and give back to those who have given so much.  To see the smile on the face of not only our veterans, but also their families, as they do something they thought they would never do again is priceless. 

 

Every donation, however small goes directly to the veterans, like Aaron, to assist in their rehabilitation and improves the quality of their lives. 

 OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Not everyone can donate and those who can’t may help us spread the word about our efforts and bring potential contributors to our campaign.  Please use the share tools on the Indiegogo site also.

 

Please visit our web-site - www.bluewaterwarriors.org and also please like us on Facebook – Blue Water Warriors.

story:
Help us launch The Kale Tea Project!                 

          We need to come up with $10,000.00

                    to get our Kale Tea bottled.

 

          

 

The Kale Tea Project is Driven by 3 Objectives:

Objective No. 1 - DRINK MORE KALE!

Kale is the hottest superfood on the planet. We won’t bore you with all the data and details. We intend to bottle up all those nutrients & antioxidants in a super tasty Ready to Drink (RTD) beverage and put it on store shelves everywhere!

But, for that to happen, we need to raise $10,000 to fund our first bottling production run. We are confident that once Kale Tea™ gets into the hands of you, the consumer, the rest will fall into place. Join the Rooftop Revolution and back our project!

Objective No. 2 - Provide a healthy alternative to Sugary drinks.

We believe that sometimes less is more. What would you prefer, Kale, mint and water...or 12 teaspoons of sugar and a laundry list of chemicals that you can’t pronounce? Think before you drink. 

Skeptics might think Kale Tea™ can’t possibly be healthy and taste good. Well, we did a taste test with the toughest focus group there is...kids. Guess what? They gave it their thumbs up. Now that’s Sweet!

Just in case you were wondering if we are a one trick pony...right now we have 3 different flavors ready to go. And we are constantly holding mixology sessions to come up with more. And did I mention that we we have collaborated with James Beard award winning Chef Alan Wong? Chef Alan loves Kale Tea™ and is currently tapping his creative juices to create an incredibly delicious world class Kale Tea™ flavor that is worthy of his Signature. Uh, yea...it's going to rock!

Objective No. 3 - Establish Rooftop Farms in Cities across the Country & across the World!

Cities occupy just 2% of the earth, yet they consume 75% of its resources. Looking down from space you would see that 1/3 of our cities are flat roofs, which are doing nothing but reflecting heat, looking ugly, and taking up space.

Our BIG food system just loves our densely populated cities, aka; "food deserts" because they can pack trains, planes and automobiles full of food (or what they call food) and make huge profits. The System calls this "Centralization". We call it "Unsustainable".

So, what can we do to change the System? How about transforming some of those wasted rooftops into thriving organic farms that feed the very people that live in its shadow?  Those same rooftop farms can provide children with hands-on learning experiences, train the next generation of "Green Collar" entrepreneurs, and support local food economies. Great idea, but who's going to pay for them you ask? WE are. WE, as in you, me, and all the drinkers of Kale Tea™.

Yup, Crowd-sourcing rooftop farms...that’s our plan. Let me explain. 10 cents from every bottle of Kale Tea™ sold will be donated to the FarmRoof® Foundation, which in turn will donate rooftop farms to schools, non-profits, and other deserving organizations across the country and across the world.

 

BEFORE - Wasted Roof Space at Castle Medical Center

 

AFTER - Organic Farm (let thy food be thy medicine)

 

Rooftop Farms? That’s Crazy!

You're probably thinking to yourself, putting dirt on roofs is asking for trouble, it’s too heavy, the roof is going to leak, it’s Pie-In-The-Sky thinking, right??? Well, we just so happened to have invented the FarmRoof®, the World's first and only certified organic food producing green roof system.  And, we operate more rooftop farms than anyone else in the World (none of which have a leaky roof). So...we kinda know what we are talking about.

Take my word for it, Rooftop Farming WILL flourish in our cities, but it's going to take WE the people to make it happen. Let's Do This!

Top 10 Benefits of a FarmRoof®

 

Risks & Challenges

Since we are launching a new ready to drink (RTD) bottled tea, the small kitchen brews just won't cut it any more. Luckily we have an awesome micro-brewery that is supporting our mission and totally on board and ready to help. However, because we are using high quality organic ingredients and a sleek glass bottle, we need to have minimum bottling runs in order to get all the costs down so that we can make this an affordable beverage. Reaching our $10,000 funding goal will allow us to economically produce our first flavor of Kale Tea™. The more we raise, the more we can brew.

While we don't expect to replace soda entirely (O.K., I admit it, I occasionally enjoy an ice cold soda), we do dream of making a splash in the beverage world. Being a small family business with limited funds, we are going to need a lot of supporters just like you to bring our dream to fruition. We want to touch as many people's lives as we can and promote healthy lifestyles and rooftop agriculture in cities across the Country and across the World. We want Kale Tea™ to be available in stores everywhere. With your support, we can Change the System! So please, spread the word and pass this link along to your family, friends, and co-workers.

Together, we can reshape the Beverage Industry and Make History! Aloha!
story_txt:
Help us launch The Kale Tea Project!                 
          We need to come up with $10,000.00
                    to get our Kale Tea bottled.
 
          

 
The Kale Tea Project is Driven by 3 Objectives:
Objective No. 1 - DRINK MORE KALE!
Kale is the hottest superfood on the planet. We won’t bore you with all the data and details. We intend to bottle up all those nutrients & antioxidants in a super tasty Ready to Drink (RTD) beverage and put it on store shelves everywhere!
But, for that to happen, we need to raise $10,000 to fund our first bottling production run. We are confident that once Kale Tea™ gets into the hands of you, the consumer, the rest will fall into place. Join the Rooftop Revolution and back our project!
Objective No. 2 - Provide a healthy alternative to Sugary drinks.
We believe that sometimes less is more. What would you prefer, Kale, mint and water...or 12 teaspoons of sugar and a laundry list of chemicals that you can’t pronounce? Think before you drink. 
Skeptics might think Kale Tea™ can’t possibly be healthy and taste good. Well, we did a taste test with the toughest focus group there is...kids. Guess what? They gave it their thumbs up. Now that’s Sweet!
Just in case you were wondering if we are a one trick pony...right now we have 3 different flavors ready to go. And we are constantly holding mixology sessions to come up with more. And did I mention that we we have collaborated with James Beard award winning Chef Alan Wong? Chef Alan loves Kale Tea™ and is currently tapping his creative juices to create an incredibly delicious world class Kale Tea™ flavor that is worthy of his Signature. Uh, yea...it's going to rock!
Objective No. 3 - Establish Rooftop Farms in Cities across the Country & across the World!
Cities occupy just 2% of the earth, yet they consume 75% of its resources. Looking down from space you would see that 1/3 of our cities are flat roofs, which are doing nothing but reflecting heat, looking ugly, and taking up space.
Our BIG food system just loves our densely populated cities, aka; "food deserts" because they can pack trains, planes and automobiles full of food (or what they call food) and make huge profits. The System calls this "Centralization". We call it "Unsustainable".
So, what can we do to change the System? How about transforming some of those wasted rooftops into thriving organic farms that feed the very people that live in its shadow?  Those same rooftop farms can provide children with hands-on learning experiences, train the next generation of "Green Collar" entrepreneurs, and support local food economies. Great idea, but who's going to pay for them you ask? WE are. WE, as in you, me, and all the drinkers of Kale Tea™.
Yup, Crowd-sourcing rooftop farms...that’s our plan. Let me explain. 10 cents from every bottle of Kale Tea™ sold will be donated to the FarmRoof® Foundation, which in turn will donate rooftop farms to schools, non-profits, and other deserving organizations across the country and across the world.
 
BEFORE - Wasted Roof Space at Castle Medical Center
 

AFTER - Organic Farm (let thy food be thy medicine)
 
Rooftop Farms? That’s Crazy!
You're probably thinking to yourself, putting dirt on roofs is asking for trouble, it’s too heavy, the roof is going to leak, it’s Pie-In-The-Sky thinking, right??? Well, we just so happened to have invented the FarmRoof®, the World's first and only certified organic food producing green roof system.  And, we operate more rooftop farms than anyone else in the World (none of which have a leaky roof). So...we kinda know what we are talking about.
Take my word for it, Rooftop Farming WILL flourish in our cities, but it's going to take WE the people to make it happen. Let's Do This!
Top 10 Benefits of a FarmRoof®

 

Risks & Challenges
Since we are launching a new ready to drink (RTD) bottled tea, the small kitchen brews just won't cut it any more. Luckily we have an awesome micro-brewery that is supporting our mission and totally on board and ready to help. However, because we are using high quality organic ingredients and a sleek glass bottle, we need to have minimum bottling runs in order to get all the costs down so that we can make this an affordable beverage. Reaching our $10,000 funding goal will allow us to economically produce our first flavor of Kale Tea™. The more we raise, the more we can brew.
While we don't expect to replace soda entirely (O.K., I admit it, I occasionally enjoy an ice cold soda), we do dream of making a splash in the beverage world. Being a small family business with limited funds, we are going to need a lot of supporters just like you to bring our dream to fruition. We want to touch as many people's lives as we can and promote healthy lifestyles and rooftop agriculture in cities across the Country and across the World. We want Kale Tea™ to be available in stores everywhere. With your support, we can Change the System! So please, spread the word and pass this link along to your family, friends, and co-workers.
Together, we can reshape the Beverage Industry and Make History! Aloha!

story:
Short Summary

When I was born, the doctors thought I was blind. After a little debating they determined that I did have sight, just not a significant amount. So, at the age of 2, I started wearing glasses. They were a definite help, but not enough. I still ran into things and got hurt on numerous occasions because I just couldnt see well enough.

 

The Doctors told my dad, that there were certanties that we would have to deal with in regards to my life, and how it would be lived. I would not be able to play sports when the time came. I shouldn't be allowed to ride a bike by myself, because I was likely to get hit by a car or just run into things. The biggest and most dissapointing thing though, was that I would never be allowed to drive. Or even attempt to. Even if I wanted to, my eyes would not allow me the safety required to get around.

 

All of these things didn't seem like big deals at the time. However, I got older, and I wanted to play sports, but wasn't able to. That is until I found wrestling. Wrestling was the one sport that I could feel my way through. I did well when I got the opportunity during gym class. My dad eventually broke down and got me my own bike, and that was probably the happiest moment of my childhood. Being able to ride around the block with my friends and jump off of ramps was the best ever back then. The only time I ever got hurt was when I tried to do something new. Young boys are daredevils and I was no exception.

 

The one thing that has always escaped me was the ability to drive. I knew that no matter how much I wanted to, and no matter how much I practiced, I just would not be safe on the road. Not for myself, but for everyone else. Everyone has heard the phrase "stay off the sidewalks" whenever a friend or young relative gets their license. That is how everyone would feel were I to have gotten mine.

 

It seemed like there may be no hope for me, and I would always have to rely on other people in order to do some of the most basic things. For the most part I have always been pretty self reliant. With work, I have always lived in an area where I could just walk to work. Or to the store, or bank. However, when I got married, we moved out of town to be closer to her grandparents, who help out with our child. Now, I live so far away from everything, that walking is no longer an option. For the first time in my life, driving has become a necessity. I finally found a doctor who was proficient enough in the surgery I needed for me to take the risk. So, on August 13th, 2012, I will be getting surgery on my eyes in hopes that I will have vision enough to drive. The ultimate goal is to get my eyes to 20/40 or better. This will net me a whole new outlook on life. Not just driving. I will see things i have never seen before.

What We Need & What You Get

The insurance that my wife and I have is great.  However, there are certain aspects to the surgery that they will not pay for. This leaves us with a little added cost that we won't be able to cover alone.

  • $1750 is the total cost of the lenses they are going to surgically place in my eyes. This is the most important part of my surgery. Without these lenses, the surgery does not happen.
  • $295 is the deductable. This has to be paid before the insurance company will write a check to the doctor
  • $750 is for miscellaneous. Because of the multiple appointents that have to happens before, during, and after the surgery, my wife will end up missing an entire week or more of work. This would not be so bad if the appointments were right in town, or even remotely close. The problem is that the appointments (6 so far) are 2 hours away. So this portion will help go towards gas, and a hotel room for two nights. Because the surgery is on the eye, they will need to have a 24hr post op check-up. So rather than waste gas on 8 hours of driving, we will most likely stay the night.
  • $200 will go to fees that are related to this site and paypal..

I don't want people to think that I am taking advantage of them in any way, so I have decided that any excess money will be put back into this program. For those who donate (and I thank you sincerely) anything over $250, will get to help choose what project(s) the excess money will go toward.

The Impact

The impact is hard to explain. Imagine not being able to see raindrops when its pouring outside. Not being able to see an airplane flying just over your head. Imagine not being able to see your wife, husband, child until they are right up on you. Not being able to go to the movies because you can't really see the screen no matter how close you are. Or people looking at you funny because your face is literally buried in a book because that is the only way you can read it.

 

Now imagine that is your life. That is how you are and nothing is going to change that. Then... something does. Someone comes aloong and says "I can fix that for you. I can give you the ability to read a book, see raindrops and airplanes. Go the movies with your family. I can change all of this for you."  

 

The impact this will have on my life is invaluable and indescribable.  It is an unbelievable feeling to know that for the first time in my entire life, I might be able to live completely free.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can tell your friends. Your family. Anyone and everyone you know. Not just about my story, but about all of the little miracles on this website that they could be a part of.

story:
The TARA Approach for the Resolution of Shock and Trauma is a Healing System With Four Unique Attributes:

  1. It differentiates shock from trauma.
  2. It is self-care and empowerment based. Its purpose is to allow everyone to be in the center of his or her own healing process.
  3. It advocates and teaches the use of subtle energy medicine as the most effective treatment of shock and trauma.
  4. The TARA Approach serves communities as well as individuals in need. It serves via a non-profit organizational structure committed to providing resources for a variety of communities, including people living with AIDS and HIV, survivors of sexual abuse and domestic violence, and parents and children.

Stephanie Mines has not only created this fusion, she has tested it clinically, developed all the training manuals for it, and written three books that document it.

The TARA Approach is under the auspices of the Dom Project, a 501.c.3 nonprofit organization that she also founded.


Will You Make A Contribution?

Your donation will support outreach to families around the world, research in sustainable healthcare that proves its effectiveness, documentation of family clinics, and program development. 

Keep this brilliant, unique, creative organization fluid and growing with your donation in any amount.

Show your encouragement, love and support for the astounding creativity of Stephanie Mines.


A Note From Stephanie's Daughters

Since 1911 International Women's Day has been held on March 8th. This year the theme is INSPIRING CHANGE. When we heard about this we immediately thought of our Mom, Stephanie Mines. We are so proud of her because she has spent her whole life Inspiring Change. Our mom has shown us what hard work means and no one knows better than we do how tirelessly she works to help families everywhere. For this year's International Women's Day we would like to help her out for a change and really show her how much the world respects her. We want her to know how incredible it is to have her as our mother.

Mom's tireless efforts sustain every function of this organization from creating the healthcare materials and protocols to distributing and implementing them. She writes, teaches, conducts family clinics, and does most of the organization's administrative work. We think it is time to show her how much she is appreciated.

~ Sierra and Rachel


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about The TARA Approach!

Education about shock – its treatment and resolution – is critical to ending violence individually, in families, in communities, and worldwide.

The TARA Approach is devoted to this education. It encourages people to be proactive to resolve shock and trauma in their own bodies and in their communities.
Education takes place most effectively through an organic process that encourages people who have experienced the healing power of this work to share it with others.

story:
Oliver's Story

Here is the background on Oliver's heart condition, as told by his mom, Chrissy. 

"On May 7th, we welcomed Oliver to our family. He was a beautiful 8lb 12oz baby and we had no idea that anything was wrong. One of the wonderful nurses discovered a heart murmur that changed our lives. He was so healthy and strong that we all thought his murmur was not serious but they called a cardiologist to come in to be sure. He discovered Oliver had a serious congenital heart defect and we had to move over to Egleston immediately.

Oliver had several issues with his heart but the main diagnosis was an IAA (interrupted aortic arch). The aorta, which carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the body, was not fully formed. This normally prevents any blood flow from circulating to the body and lower extremities but Oliver had two other defects that kept his blood flowing and masked that he was even having any trouble. He also had a PDA (patent ductus arteriosus). This is a connection between the pulmonary artery (the vessel that brings deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs) and the aorta which allows blood flow to bipass the lungs during fetal circulation. Usually, this closes very quickly after birth but with Oliver, it stayed open. This connection allowed some of the blood to flow from the pulmonary artery to the lower part of the aortic arch, bringing blood to the body. The third defect is a VSD (ventricular septal defect) which is a hole between the ventricles. This defect allowed the oxygenated and deoxygenated blood to mix in the heart. Instead of deoxygenated blood being carried through the pulmonary artery, mixed blood flowed through and brought oxygen to his body. Although he was stable before his surgery, his condition would have changed very quickly if the PDA closed. We are so thankful that it was discovered early.

Oliver was given a medication to keep his PDA open and that bought us time at Egleston to plan Oliver's surgery. After many tests, the surgical team decided they would have to do a stepped approach to Oliver's repair rather than one surgery to fix his heart. Due to the changes in his blood flow, parts of his heart and vessels did not develop as large as they normally would and he would need multiple surgeries and time to grow in between.

At one week old, Oliver had his first open heart surgery. Dr. Kanter went in to repair the arch and preformed a procedure called the Norwood. This is usually done on babies with only one ventricle which allows mixed blood (oxygenated and deoxygenated) to flow throughout the body. They left the VSD allowing his blood to mix and used his PDA to aid in rebuilding the arch as well his pulmonary artery. Finally, they placed a shunt (artificial vessel) to act as the pulmonary artery and take blood to the lungs. This temporary repair allowed Oliver to grow but the shunt was small and would need replacing in 6-9 months. The surgery was very complex and took almost 12 hours to complete but Dr. Kanter made sure the repair was perfect.

We were able to see Oliver after surgery and at that time it well past midnight. His chest was open due to swelling and he had many chest tubes and lines coming out of him. I couldn't even recognize him laying there. It was such a horrible sight. He was still on the breathing tube and sedated so we went home to rest after our long day.

The next morning I arrived early and was there until mid afternoon. I hadn't really slept and the nurse urged me to go home and get some sleep. Oliver was doing well and the critical 12 hour period after surgery had passed. I finally gave in, feeling exhausted. Shortly after I left his heart stopped. I had barely been home when we got the call. They were not able to get his heart functioning but they were able to put him on ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) which is a heart lung bypass machine. This machine does the work of Oliver's lungs and heart while allowing his heart time to recover. I am so thankful that ECMO exisits but it is not something you ever want to need. When we arrived back at Egleston, there were more connections coming out of his chest, carrying the blood out of his body to ECMO and back in again. Five days passed and the doctors felt they could try to take him off. We were warned before that if it was not successful now, he would not likely survive but he was strong and regained function of his heart.

After a couple days and a chest closure later, it was time to try to get him off his vent and get him breathing on his own. Each time we extubated him from the vent he had respiratory distress and collapse of his left lung. After several days of trying different things, the doctors discovered his left diaphragm was moving in the opposite direction than it should. Instead moving down and helping the lung open when Oliver took a breath, it pushed up and, along with some fluid in the lung, caused it to keep collapsing.

The solution to this was to have another surgery. They did what was called a diaphragm plication. This is where they go in through the ribs and tie the diaphragm down in the open position preventing it from pushing against the lung. He did well with this surgery and we were finally able to get him off the breathing tube.

The next hurdle to get over was feeding. We started feeding Oliver tiny amounts through a feeding tube that ran through his nose. He was not able to tolerate even the smallest amounts of food and we discovered he had severe acid reflux. Now we were facing yet another surgery. This time, Oliver had a fundoplication and a g-tube placed. A fundoplication is where the surgeon wraps part of the stomach around the base of the esophagus and the upper part of the stomach allowing food to go in but preventing anything from coming out. This kept the reflux from traveling up his esophagus and causing him to throw up. The g-tube is a tube placed into the stomach through the wall of the abdomen. This is where his feeding primarily took place but with the help of time and feeding therapy, the doctors were confident that he would be able to have the g-tube removed.

We were finally able to feed him with the help of the tube and we were increasing feedings gradually to his reach his goal. Again, he was breathing on his own after being on the vent again for the third surgery. We were hoping to get him out of the ICU when he developed an arrythmia that could be life threatening. He still had an external pacemaker thankfully and they were able to control it while they tested different antiarrythmia medications to treat it. Many of these drugs could cause harmful side effects so finding a balance was a delicate and time consuming project.

After some time, arrythmia controlled, we were transferred to the cardiac step-down unit where we learned more about how to care for Oliver at home. He had a dizzying 13 medications to be administered throughout the day and he was getting his feedings through a pump into his tube. There was a lot to learn in just a couple short days. It was seven weeks to the day and we were finally discharged home.

Almost two months late, we brought our baby home from the hospital. After an adjustment period, we developed a routine. We juggled many appointments with the cardiologist, feeding therapist, physical therapist, pulmonologist, gasteroenterologist, and pediatrician. It was hard at first but we were all so relieved to be together as a family again. Even Lewis adored his baby brother dispite him getting much of the attention.

Over the last six months, Oliver has been getting bigger and stronger. He is down to just three medications and only uses his feeding tube at night. He nurses during the day and even eats solids now! We had several hospitalizations over that time but they were due to a stomach virus, bad cold or the flu. Due to the delicate nature of the first repair, the doctors are cautious with him and we were admitted to Egleston more frequently than we would have liked."

Latest update after 2nd surgery:

"Oliver is in stable condition and the doctors are pleased. He's not totally out of the woods but since he did so great with surgery, he will likely have an uncomplicated recovery. We are hoping for a quick stay in the ICU. You will be amazed at how fast
all those tubes will come out, leaving him looking like Oliver again. I can't wait!!"


Jan 19th update,

We all hoped for a quick, uncomplicated recovery for Oliver. We don't always get what we hope for. I wanted to post an update that Oliver's mom, Chrissy wrote a few days ago about the experience she's been going through these past days and months. 

"As you can probably imangine, the ICU is a hectic place. The cardiac ICU at Egleston is very open. You can look up and down and see other patients, families, nurses, doctors, tons of equipment. Nothing much is hidden, it's all out in the open. You can see when someone is having a good day like yesterday when a crib arrived for my neighbor. That meant they were being transferred to the step down unit. The bad days are evident too. Today was one of those days. Emergencies erupted all over the unit today. I had a difficult, tearful day but I know that others had it worse. One nurse touched my shoulder and commented that there were a lot of tears in the ICU today. It made me realize that I'm not alone. I know how fortunate I am that I will mostly likely bring my baby home with me. It may not be on my timeline but I will. Some others will not be so fortunate. I left this evening and noticed a couple in the consult room, tear soaked faces with a tiny baby not far away with doctors huddled around. Lowell and I were once that couple. I felt so terrible for them but it also made me realize how much we have overcome in this past 8 months. The ICU is a horrible and wonderful place. So much healing and heartache surrounds it. I am in awe of the doctors and nurses that can face that place each day. They are truly special people."

-Christine Thompson

For those interested, you can visit http://www.carepages.com/carepages/OliversHeart to receive daily updates on Oliver's progress. 


We can't wait either. That's why we're appealing to you for help.

  • Oliver will need a lot of care and attention over the next few months.
  • Chrissy hasn't been able to work a full week since he was born due to the extensive care Oliver requires. 
  • Day to day expenses, as well as huge medical bills are adding up during this very difficult and trying time.

The Impact

Anything you can give, no matter how small, will have a huge impact on Oliver's recovery. The less time Chrissy and Lowell spend worrying about bills the more time they can spend with Oliver.

He discovered Oliver had a serious congenital heart defect and we had to move over to Egleston immediately.Oliver had several issues with his heart but the main diagnosis was an IAA (interrupted aortic arch). The aorta, which carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the body, was not fully formed. This normally prevents any blood flow from circulating to the body and lower extremities but Oliver had two other defects that kept his blood flowing and masked that he was even having any trouble. He also had a PDA (patent ductus arteriosus). This is a connection between the pulmonary artery (the vessel that brings deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs) and the aorta which allows blood flow to bipass the lungs during fetal circulation. Usually, this closes very quickly after birth but with Oliver, it stayed open. This connection allowed some of the blood to flow from the pulmonary artery to the lower part of the aortic arch, bringing blood to the body. The third defect is a VSD (ventricular septal defect) which is a hole between the ventricles. This defect allowed the oxygenated and deoxygenated blood to mix in the heart. Instead of deoxygenated blood being carried through the pulmonary artery, mixed blood flowed through and brought oxygen to his body. Although he was stable before his surgery, his condition would have changed very quickly if the PDA closed. We are so thankful that it was discovered early.Oliver was given a medication to keep his PDA open and that bought us time at Egleston to plan Oliver's surgery. After many tests, the surgical team decided they would have to do a stepped approach to Oliver's repair rather than one surgery to fix his heart. Due to the changes in his blood flow, parts of his heart and vessels did not develop as large as they normally would and he would need multiple surgeries and time to grow in between.At one week old, Oliver had his first open heart surgery. Dr. Kanter went in to repair the arch and preformed a procedure called the Norwood. This is usually done on babies with only one ventricle which allows mixed blood (oxygenated and deoxygenated) to flow throughout the body. They left the VSD allowing his blood to mix and used his PDA to aid in rebuilding the arch as well his pulmonary artery. Finally, they placed a shunt (artificial vessel) to act as the pulmonary artery and take blood to the lungs. This temporary repair allowed Oliver to grow but the shunt was small and would need replacing in 6-9 months. The surgery was very complex and took almost 12 hours to complete but Dr. Kanter made sure the repair was perfect.We were able to see Oliver after surgery and at that time it well past midnight. His chest was open due to swelling and he had many chest tubes and lines coming out of him. I couldn't even recognize him laying there. It was such a horrible sight. He was still on the breathing tube and sedated so we went home to rest after our long day.The next morning I arrived early and was there until mid afternoon. I hadn't really slept and the nurse urged me to go home and get some sleep. Oliver was doing well and the critical 12 hour period after surgery had passed. I finally gave in, feeling exhausted. Shortly after I left his heart stopped. I had barely been home when we got the call. They were not able to get his heart functioning but they were able to put him on ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) which is a heart lung bypass machine. This machine does the work of Oliver's lungs and heart while allowing his heart time to recover. I am so thankful that ECMO exisits but it is not something you ever want to need. When we arrived back at Egleston, there were more connections coming out of his chest, carrying the blood out of his body to ECMO and back in again. Five days passed and the doctors felt they could try to take him off. We were warned before that if it was not successful now, he would not likely survive but he was strong and regained function of his heart.After a couple days and a chest closure later, it was time to try to get him off his vent and get him breathing on his own. Each time we extubated him from the vent he had respiratory distress and collapse of his left lung. After several days of trying different things, the doctors discovered his left diaphragm was moving in the opposite direction than it should. Instead moving down and helping the lung open when Oliver took a breath, it pushed up and, along with some fluid in the lung, caused it to keep collapsing.The solution to this was to have another surgery. They did what was called a diaphragm plication. This is where they go in through the ribs and tie the diaphragm down in the open position preventing it from pushing against the lung. He did well with this surgery and we were finally able to get him off the breathing tube.The next hurdle to get over was feeding. We started feeding Oliver tiny amounts through a feeding tube that ran through his nose. He was not able to tolerate even the smallest amounts of food and we discovered he had severe acid reflux. Now we were facing yet another surgery. This time, Oliver had a fundoplication and a g-tube placed. A fundoplication is where the surgeon wraps part of the stomach around the base of the esophagus and the upper part of the stomach allowing food to go in but preventing anything from coming out. This kept the reflux from traveling up his esophagus and causing him to throw up. The g-tube is a tube placed into the stomach through the wall of the abdomen. This is where his feeding primarily took place but with the help of time and feeding therapy, the doctors were confident that he would be able to have the g-tube removed.We were finally able to feed him with the help of the tube and we were increasing feedings gradually to his reach his goal. Again, he was breathing on his own after being on the vent again for the third surgery. We were hoping to get him out of the ICU when he developed an arrythmia that could be life threatening. He still had an external pacemaker thankfully and they were able to control it while they tested different antiarrythmia medications to treat it. Many of these drugs could cause harmful side effects so finding a balance was a delicate and time consuming project.After some time, arrythmia controlled, we were transferred to the cardiac step-down unit where we learned more about how to care for Oliver at home. He had a dizzying 13 medications to be administered throughout the day and he was getting his feedings through a pump into his tube. There was a lot to learn in just a couple short days. It was seven weeks to the day and we were finally discharged home.Almost two months late, we brought our baby home from the hospital. After an adjustment period, we developed a routine. We juggled many appointments with the cardiologist, feeding therapist, physical therapist, pulmonologist, gasteroenterologist, and pediatrician. It was hard at first but we were all so relieved to be together as a family again. Even Lewis adored his baby brother dispite him getting much of the attention.Over the last six months, Oliver has been getting bigger and stronger. He is down to just three medications and only uses his feeding tube at night. He nurses during the day and even eats solids now! We had several hospitalizations over that time but they were due to a stomach virus, bad cold or the flu. Due to the delicate nature of the first repair, the doctors are cautious with him and we were admitted to Egleston more frequently than we would have liked."Latest update after 2nd surgery:"Oliver is in stable condition and the doctors are pleased. He's not totally out of the woods but since he did so great with surgery, he will likely have an uncomplicated recovery. We are hoping for a quick stay in the ICU. You will be amazed at how fastall those tubes will come out, leaving him looking like Oliver again. I can't wait!!"Jan 19th update,We all hoped for a quick, uncomplicated recovery for Oliver. We don't always get what we hope for. I wanted to post an update that Oliver's mom, Chrissy wrote a few days ago about the experience she's been going through these past days and months. "As you can probably imangine, the ICU is a hectic place. The cardiac ICU at Egleston is very open. You can look up and down and see other patients, families, nurses, doctors, tons of equipment. Nothing much is hidden, it's all out in the open. You can see when someone is having a good day like yesterday when a crib arrived for my neighbor. That meant they were being transferred to the step down unit. The bad days are evident too. Today was one of those days. Emergencies erupted all over the unit today. I had a difficult, tearful day but I know that others had it worse. One nurse touched my shoulder and commented that there were a lot of tears in the ICU today. It made me realize that I'm not alone. I know how fortunate I am that I will mostly likely bring my baby home with me. It may not be on my timeline but I will. Some others will not be so fortunate. I left this evening and noticed a couple in the consult room, tear soaked faces with a tiny baby not far away with doctors huddled around. Lowell and I were once that couple. I felt so terrible for them but it also made me realize how much we have overcome in this past 8 months. The ICU is a horrible and wonderful place. So much healing and heartache surrounds it. I am in awe of the doctors and nurses that can face that place each day. They are truly special people."-Christine ThompsonFor those interested, you can visit http://www.carepages.com/carepages/OliversHeart to receive daily updates on Oliver's progress. We can't wait either. That's why we're appealing to you for help.
Oliver will need a lot of care and attention over the next few months.
Chrissy hasn't been able to work a full week since he was born due to the extensive care Oliver requires. 
Day to day expenses, as well as huge medical bills are adding up during this very difficult and trying time.
The ImpactAnything you can give, no matter how small, will have a huge impact on Oliver's recovery. The less time Chrissy and Lowell spend worrying about bills the more time they can spend with Oliver.

story:
About My Campaign:

My name is Elyse Wilson and I have recently committed my life to fitness, wellness, and the practice of yoga.  Through this campaign, I am going to follow my goal of transitioning from a full-time NYC public school teacher to a yoga instructor and tutor for students with special needs. Ultimately, my goal is to see blending my love of yoga and and passion for working with students with disabilities into a practice that will give an underserved population access to health and wellness. 

 I have struggled with body and weight ever since I can remember.  I applied for and was chosen to participate in the 12 week B.E.S.T. program at Human@Ease. Their integrative approach to health and wellness combines mind, body, soul, and community.  I went from 170lbs to 141lbs, and decreased my body fat from 31% to 19%.  I owe most of my fitness success from discovering my passion for yoga, a practice that has changed my life. Here is my blog that has documented continuing journey towards health and wellness.

With your donations, I will complete a 200-hr Yoga Alliance Certified Yoga Sukhavati Teacher Training. I look forward to having the opportunity to share practice and passion with members of the community who struggle with their weight and mental health.  I also look forward to sharing my practice at schools and community centers that cater to underserved and underrepresented youth.  I've found peace with my mind and body through yoga, and I am eager to inspire others on their transformational journey to health and fitness.

By contributing to my teacher training campaign, you will be furthering my education and practice of yoga with the following educational curriculum:

• The proper alignment, benefits & potential risks of the foundational yoga postures

• Principles of anatomy and how they apply to each posture

• The science and art of sequencing a yoga class

• Hands on adjustments

• How to observe and see bodies

• The art of the voice

• Confidence through practice teaching

• Yoga history and philosophy

• An introduction into subtle body, ayurveda and meditation

• Sanskrit names of the postures

At the completion of my campaign and teacher training, I will be able to register with Yoga Alliance at the RYT-200 Level.  From there, I will be working to serve private clients, community yoga centers, as well as yoga by donation.  

What We Need & What You Get

100% of the @3600 is going towards my early registration for 200-hour  teacher training, which will begin July 29th and run through August 29th.  

There are great perks for contributions ranging from $1 to $100! Anything you contribute will make a difference to my campaign.

The Impact

I have experienced firsthand the transformative power of practicing yoga.  Before my practice, I was overweight, depressed and on medication, not sleeping well, not giving 100% at work, and struggling with self esteem and social life.  Now, I am at a healthy weight, have developed a passion and talent for creating community with health and wellness, and have improved my relationships at home and at work.  I now have the opportunity to help others achieve the same qualities of life that I have found through my integrative approach to health and wellness that is centered around the practice of yoga.

Since I started practicing yoga in August 2013, friends, family and neighbors have reached out to me through my blog and social media expressing their gratitude for sharing my story, as well as any questions and tips for starting a routine.  By enrolling and inspired friends, family, and neighbors to commit to a health and fitness routine, it has confirmed my desire to change lives through sharing my practice.

In addition to my own mind and body transformation, my experience as a high school teacher makes me a perfect candidate to transition to yoga teacher.  I am comfortable running classes, managing student questions and concerns, modeling in front of a class, and giving positive feedback while challenging my students to create and reach their own goals.  

As I complete the 200-hour teacher certification, I will transition from working as a full time high school teacher to a yoga instructor and tutor for special needs students.  Down the line, I can even see blending my love of yoga and and passion for working with students with disabilities into a practice that will give an underserved population access to health and wellness. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help me reach my goal.  Please spread the word by using Indiegogo share tools!

My sincere gratitude,

Elyse Wilson

story:
Help me raise money to send my sister, Amanda, on a volunteer internship to impact the lives of the underprivileged living in Ghana. This internship is organized by Interexchange, a non-profit organization devoted to promoting cross-cultural awareness through work and volunteer exchange programs. She is expected to work at least 20 hours a week and will be in Ghana, from June 15, 2014 until July 20, 2014.

Let me tell you about my sister Amanda. She is 18 years old and is attending Carleton College in Minnesota. She is currently studying pre-medicine and plans on going to Medical School. Amanda is passionate about serving others that are less fortunate then she as she says it gives her perspective in life and a reason to work hard and to learn. She wants to use her knowledge and skills to help people who are underprivileged. Two summers ago, she made a similar trip with some classmates to an orphanage in China. There she administered care to physically and mentally disabled children who were undernourished and unloved. She spent most of her time on the second floor with the ‘untouchables’ or the children who were severely disabled and could not move. When she recalls upon the memories of her friends she made there, it brings her to tears. 

Amanda will be working hard in a local Ghanaian Hospital. She is going to be working on the outskirts of the town Wale Wale at Langbensi, a Presbyterian Church health clinic. Their main objective is to reach out with health care and make it available to the most deprived people in rural areas. The volunteers will be appointed to tasks such as registering patients and doing initial exams, immunizing and taking their blood, and working at a children’s ward.

Our family had always had a running joke that my sister, her caring, personable, and empathetic self would save the world. While as I, my technological, mathematical and science-loving self, would finance her. This may have seemed like a joke before, but I had always planned on something like this, to make sure my sister could carry out her dreams. However at this stage in my life I am jobless and do not have enough personal money to sponsor Amanda. I have a personal project at school, a long-term project for my MYP diploma. This turned out to be a perfect opportunity to start making an impact. My goal is to raise enough money to send Amanda on this internship. The proceeds will be used for the airline fees, program costs and room and board. Additional funds will be donated to the Langbensi Presbyterian Clinic.

This is where you as donors come into the picture. Amanda and I need you to make this project a success and help the people in need in Ghana. If money is a problem, you do not have to donate much or even donate at all. All we are asking for is as much support as you can offer and for you to share this with your friends and family through Facebook and other social networking sites.

Another issue is that often people donate money without knowing exactly what it will be used for. I have thought of a solution to this. Amanda will be sending me weekly blogs to update you and to allow you to see what your money is being used for. I will post these on my blog page. I have already created the first blog post as an overview of Ghana. 

Thank you for your support!

story:
Be The Best Sport

Around 5 years ago, we were approached to start a soccer program for children with Autism. 5 years later we are still running that same program and more. Since the first program started, we decided that something more substantial needed to be done. Our mission at Be The Best Sport is to provide enjoyable and exciting programs for children with special needs. The program is designed to provide a fun, yet challenging setting in which children will develop both individual sport skills and learn the important values of teamwork and social interaction. This program offers the athletes an opportunity to have fun without the stress of being observed by doctors or any other medical professionals. 

Currently, our basketball, multi-sport and soccer programs have brought a lot of success, development, and fun to both the children and their families. Professional coaches and dedicated volunteers help the athletes acquire athletic skills in these sports. In addition, Be The Best Sport organizes teams to enter into the Special Olympics. This gives these hard working athletes the opportunity to compete against others like them all over Long Island. 

April: Autism Month

For the month of April we are fundraising to spread awareness about our cause and to raise money in order to fund new programs.

As a result of the positive feedback and success we have already received, we strive to  create various new programs that will teach and enhance motor skills and socialization. 

One of the programs we aim to pursue is a bike riding class that will teach the children to ride a two wheel bicycle independently. These specialized bikes are high in price and part of the money raised would be put towards creating this new bike program and purchasing the individual bicycles. Any leftover funds would be put towards buying more equipment for our existing programs as well as creating new and exciting ones.

The Impact

Thank you so much for your time and consideration. A donation of any size is always helpful and we hope that you will be able to feel the impact that you are making on these children's lives just as much as we do. 

With each new program we create and opportunity we produce, we are providing these special needs children with a social and entertainment aspect to their life that is similar to any other kid. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Seeing the smile on a child's face while doing a soccer drill and playing with our volunteers is enough to keep this program going. The greatest action you could do to contribute is to spread the word about our campaign. Send this link out to as many friends and family members as you can or post it to your Facebook or Twitter page. Raising awareness about our program and encouraging other people to donate is equivalent, if not even more important than donating yourself. 

Thank you for supporting us! Your efforts are greatly appreciated.

story:
Hiiii! My name is Mara. I'm a graduate student finishing up my Masters and applying to medical school soon! I am here to ask for help to support my momma while she beats up some stage 3 cancer! She's a tough cookie but my family could definitely benefit from some extra money to help eliminate unnecessary financial stress!

I am asking for $1000 to help her mostly with unpaid insurance expenses as well as a nice wig to help her feel more beautiful! (She wants a purple one! Hehe.)

    The impact of this gift is hard to put into words. The encouragement and hope my mom will feel after seeing all of these people come together for her will lift her spirits tremendously! 

    Plus don't you think she will be a lot happier doing her chemo with a sassy purple wig on?!

      Cancer is tough by my mom is tougher!!! I know she will come out on top of this and together we can help make it a little easier for her! If you cannot donate feel free to send prayers or encouraging words instead! Thanks so much! Xoxo.

story:
UPDATE: WE SMASHED ALL OF OUR GOALS! And, this campaign has been chosen as part of Indiegogo's InDemand campaigns: never-ending campaigns. I don't know how this will look yet, but more details will be coming shortly. Thanks for all your support!

IF YOU WOULD LIKE A BOW TIE MADE FROM ONE OF THE NEW MATERIALS ADDED FOR THE COIN PURSES AND WRISLETS, DONATE A MINIMUM OF $30 AND LEAVE A COMMENT STATING WHICH FABRIC YOU WOULD LIKE. Unfortunately, I can't add any more perks because I've reached the limit.

NEW PERKS ADDED! COIN PURSES AND WRISLETS! SAME STRETCHED GOALS AS BOW TIES PERKS! Scroll down to near the bottom to see more about the Bow Ties Stretched Goals which apply to these perks. Larger images are in the gallery.


NEW PERKS ADDED! BOW TIES ARE COOL! BOW TIE PERKS ALSO HAVE THEIR OWN STRETCHED GOALS! Scroll down to near the bottom to see more about the Bow Ties Streched Goals. Larger images are in the gallery.


The road to GRS in B.C. is a long one, with many hoops to jump. Some of those hoops involve three different expensive psychiatric assessments. Plus, I need some gender therapy because I'm now getting dysphoria-induced nightly night terrors, and top surgery is a big decision. Having gender therapy, even if no longer required, is still necessary (IMHO) before having life and body-altering surgery.

How the Money will be Used

Ideally, I need at least $4500.00 to cover expenses over the next year or so. But, I'm starting out with a more reasonable goal. Everything on top of the $1100 will be allotted to the extra costs I'll eventually have to cover.

But for now, I need $500 for the psych assessment that will allow me to see the necessary doctors for transition purposes. Those doctors would be an Endo who will declare the fact that I cannot have HRT due to pre-existing health issues, and the 1-year-on-HRT requirement should be waved. Then, the endo will refer me to the doctor in Vancouver who will perform the top surgery.

READ IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT PERK BELOW!

Multiple trips to and from the island are not factored into these expenses.

The other $500 will be used to cover four gender therapy sessions.

The additional $100 is to cover Indiegogo and PayPal fees.

The initial $1000 will be used to reimburse my out-of-savings costs. I have my first gender therapy session on Dec 9, and my first psych assessment in a few weeks.

How Funds Over $1000 Will Be Used

The costs of $4500.00 covers the three necessary psych assessments: 1 to get referral to necessary doctors; 2 additional assessment after doctor's agree to surgery. These assessments are done by government appointed assessors who will make final recommendation to province whether or not to fund my top surgery.

The other $2900 is to cover 24 gender therapy sessions (2/month for 1 year).

The extra money is to cover fees.

Perks

I've been told by friends that perks are probably not necessary. That said, I feel obliged to offer them as a small way of saying thanks.

You, however, are under no obligation to take them. Indiegogo allows you to contribute any amount you want without selected a perk.

Or, you could save your perks for a later time, or gift them to a friend in need.

Two types of perks

All perks are virtual so that there is no need to factor in production and shipment of perks.

Every one who donates a minimum of $10 CAD will receive a digital copy of my book Five Little Zombies and Fred.

The other type of perk I'm offering are my Skookum Monkey services, at a 50% discounted rate.

See the perks column for more details.

Streched Goals!

I have them. Here is a handy-dandy infochart:


Thanks in advance for your support! While I'll never "pass" because I'll always sound like a female, having the government legally recognize me as a male and having my sex marker changed on all of my ID is of great importance to me, and it has now become a mental health necessity.

So, your support is HUGE and I'll appreciate for many reasons and in ways I'll never be able to properly articulate. So, thanks, again
story_txt: UPDATE: WE SMASHED ALL OF OUR GOALS! And, this campaign has been chosen as part of Indiegogo's InDemand campaigns: never-ending campaigns. I don't know how this will look yet, but more details will be coming shortly. Thanks for all your support!IF YOU WOULD LIKE A BOW TIE MADE FROM ONE OF THE NEW MATERIALS ADDED FOR THE COIN PURSES AND WRISLETS, DONATE A MINIMUM OF $30 AND LEAVE A COMMENT STATING WHICH FABRIC YOU WOULD LIKE. Unfortunately, I can't add any more perks because I've reached the limit.NEW PERKS ADDED! COIN PURSES AND WRISLETS! SAME STRETCHED GOALS AS BOW TIES PERKS! Scroll down to near the bottom to see more about the Bow Ties Stretched Goals which apply to these perks. Larger images are in the gallery.NEW PERKS ADDED! BOW TIES ARE COOL! BOW TIE PERKS ALSO HAVE THEIR OWN STRETCHED GOALS! Scroll down to near the bottom to see more about the Bow Ties Streched Goals. Larger images are in the gallery.The road to GRS in B.C. is a long one, with many hoops to jump. Some of those hoops involve three different expensive psychiatric assessments. Plus, I need some gender therapy because I'm now getting dysphoria-induced nightly night terrors, and top surgery is a big decision. Having gender therapy, even if no longer required, is still necessary (IMHO) before having life and body-altering surgery.How the Money will be Used Ideally, I need at least $4500.00 to cover expenses over the next year or so. But, I'm starting out with a more reasonable goal. Everything on top of the $1100 will be allotted to the extra costs I'll eventually have to cover.But for now, I need $500 for the psych assessment that will allow me to see the necessary doctors for transition purposes. Those doctors would be an Endo who will declare the fact that I cannot have HRT due to pre-existing health issues, and the 1-year-on-HRT requirement should be waved. Then, the endo will refer me to the doctor in Vancouver who will perform the top surgery.READ IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT PERK BELOW!Multiple trips to and from the island are not factored into these expenses.The other $500 will be used to cover four gender therapy sessions.The additional $100 is to cover Indiegogo and PayPal fees.The initial $1000 will be used to reimburse my out-of-savings costs. While I'll never "pass" because I'll always sound like a female, having the government legally recognize me as a male and having my sex marker changed on all of my ID is of great importance to me, and it has now become a mental health necessity.So, your support is HUGE and I'll appreciate for many reasons and in ways I'll never be able to properly articulate. So, thanks, again
We're now live on our website: www.skillboardusa.com. We ship within 2 days of receiving an order!

story:
Short Summary

1.6 million new cases of cancer are expected to be diagnosed in the US in 2015.  Many of these individuals will begin receiving one, or several, of the various cancer treatment options currently available.  Today, doctors have limited non-invasive techniques available to them to help them accurately assess the treatment's success.  With our massively parallel blood analyzer, doctors will have the ability to more quickly and less expensively measure the increase or decrease in the concentration of circulating tumor cells in the patient's bloodstream.  This is an important indicator of the effectiveness of a given course of treatment in a number of different cancers.  Our approach entails a simple and inexpensive blood test, eliminating the need for risky and painful surgical biopsies, thereby reducing the stress, discomfort and financial burden on the patient and his or her family.

What We Need & What You Get

We are interested in raising $1.6 million dollars in this campaign.  That's one dollar for every expected new case of cancer in the US in 2015.  Your contributions to our campaign will be used to accelerate the development of our important and life enhancing technology.  With your help, we can secure the manpower and equipment needed to complete the development and testing of our massively parallel blood analyzer.  This will enable us to bring our product to the marketplace in 2017, a full two years earlier than originally projected.  If we are unable to reach our full campaign goal, any funding we receive will allow us to continue to move the project forward while we secure other sources of capital.

The Impact

Cancer disrupts the lives of so many people.  It doesn't care where you live, how much money you earn or what kind of contribution you are making to the world.  Our massively parallel blood analyzer will enable doctors to quickly and easily measure the success of a current course of treatment and make changes to the treatment plan, if appropriate.  This increases the opportunity for more patients to have a better prognosis and a happier outcome.  In addition, our technology opens the door for a future diagnostic blood test for cancer that could become a standard part of your annual blood testing.

Risks & Challenges

The risk of not meeting our goals through this crowdfunding campaign is that our massively parallel blood analyzer won’t be available for clinical use until at least 2019.  Although several regulatory hurdles and many known (and some as yet unknown) technical challenges will need to be overcome before our approach can be widely accepted and used by the medical community, we strongly believe that four years is too long to wait for the millions of cancer victims who will be newly diagnosed or who will be undergoing treatment during that time frame.


Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate all contributions to our campaign, whether big or small, but we understand this might not be the right time for you to help us financially.  Another way you can help is by spreading the word about our campaign to anybody and everybody you know.   The greater the crowd we can gather, the greater our  opportunity for success.

story:
FINAL UPDATE: A big thank you to everyone who donated to this fundraiser. It turned out better than I could have ever expected when I first created it. Although this fundraiser is over donations can still be made to St. Paul which was stated in one of my previous updates below. And as always, keep up with Caleb's progress at 

http://www.caringbridge.org/visit/calebh

 

Again, thank you so much everyone again. All of the support was/is amazing. Get well soon Caleb!

 

 

UPDATE 3: Caleb is doing as well as can be expected at this point. To track the progress of his recovery, keep up with http://www.caringbridge.org/visit/calebh which is periodically updated by his aunt, Lynn. The prayers and support Caleb's family and friends have received has been unbelieveable. The fundraising has slowed a little, but that is to be expected. Which is why I propose we need to crank it back up. Right now the website is currently around $8500. Let's give that extra push to get it over $10000! Let's get everyone to reshare the website again so that people who might have missed it the first time get a chance to see it. Thanks to everyone who has already donated and for everyone's continued prayers. God Bless.

 

 

UPDATE 2: We are now accepting donations for Caleb through St. Paul church. If you or someone you know would like to donate by check make it payable to "St. Paul's Caring for Caleb" and mail it to St. Paul Lutheran Church at 1126 Barr Street Fort Wayne, IN 46802. Cash donations will also be accepted at St. Paul's as well. So, keep spreading the word about the online donations, as well as the checks or cash to St. Paul's. Thanks guys.

 

UPDATE: Thank you so much to everyone who has donated so far. The support from everyone has been overwhelming. We have easily passed the $3000 goal that I set. But we're nowhere near finished yet. We still have a month and a half left before the fund closes. Even though the goal is surpassed FUNDS ARE STILL BEING ACCEPTED. The initial support has been outstanding but it's time to take it to another level. Let's set the next goal at $10,000. With the support we've had this soon I know we can accomplish anything!

 

 

MY BEST FRIEND CALEB NEEDS YOUR HELP!

 

STORY:


On July 14th a gas leak in my best friend Caleb's house was ignited and the house literally exploded. He was the only one home at the time and the explosion shook the entire neighborhood. His neighbor was able to pull him from the rubble of the house after hearing his screams for help. He was then rushed to the burn unit at the local hospital for immediate treatment.

 

Currently, he is in stable condition at the hospital, but over 85% of his body is covered in burns, most of them third degree. He is in an induced coma right now as the doctors try to fight off infections and clear off all the dead skin. He is going to reamin in this coma for approximately a month and a half and only his immediate family will be able to see him. Once he is woken up he will then have another month and a half of surgeries and recovery in the hospital. Finally after these 3 months he will then have to go into rehab for further recovery.

Link to news story: http://www.wane.com/dpp/news/local/firefighters...


BACKGROUND:

Caleb is a 21 year old student and construction worker. He was going to move out of his house in less than a month and move to Bloomington, IN to attend Indiana University as business student. When Caleb wasn't spending time with his family you could either find Caleb at the YMCA dunking on people in basketball or attending concerts with his close friends. He is a fun loving, easy going individual & one of the best friends anyone can ask for. He was never afraid to lend help to anyone who needed it, and he was always there in times of need for his friends. Now is Caleb's time of need and he needs us more than ever.

 

 

OUR GOAL:

This is going to be an extremely long recovery process for Caleb. It will involve many surgeries and skin grafts and many many hours of rehab. Anyone who has ever been involved in medical procedures can all attest to one thing: it's very expensive. Caleb won't even be able to leave the hospital for three months. This is where we come in. I've set a goal of $3000 which I think is very attainable. I would love to make more, but one step at a time. I know in the grand scheme of things $3000 might not make that much difference in the huge medical expenses that will pile up, but any little bit can help. All donations will be given to Caleb's parents to pay for whatever medical expenses they can cover. 

 

It's important to understand that Caleb literally has nothing right now. No clothes, no computer, no shoes, no house. The only thing he does have right now is the love and support of everyone around him. When he wakes up in a month and half his entire world is going to be rocked by what he sees. The only thing that will get him through the most difficult time in his life is having people there who love and care for him unconditionally. This is why I've set the deadline as September 1st. This will be approximately the day the doctors wake Caleb up out of his coma. When he wakes up I hope to not only show him that he has the support of all his friends and family, but that he has the support of strangers that have never even met him before.

 

I understand that not everyone is able to help financially. But whether you decide to donate or not, one thing you can do is share Caleb's story. Share this page on Facebook or Twitter or whatever way you can. This young man is fighting for his life right now and he needs support from anyone who will lend it.

 

 

Anyone who is reading this I ask you, no, I beg you please look within your heart to help this beloved son, grandson, brother and true friend in his greatest time of need. THANK YOU EVERYONE FOR YOUR SUPPORT!
